stem: The nurse is assessing a 9-month-old infant during a well-child visit. Based on the provided information, indicate which findings are consistent with expected developmental milestones for the following age ranges. Select one age range for each finding.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 14:00 Nurse Amy SBAR for patient: Baby Leo, 9 months old. Situation: Baby Leo is here for a routine well-child check-up. Background: Mother reports that Leo was born at term with no complications. He has been meeting most developmental milestones, but she has some concerns about his mobility and social interaction. Assessment: On physical examination, Leo appears healthy and well-nourished. Vitals are within normal limits. He is able to sit unsupported for a short period. Leo transfers objects from one hand to the other but does not yet crawl. When a stranger approaches, Leo shows some anxiety. He babbles simple sounds like 'mama' and 'dada' without directed intent. Mother is concerned about his social interaction and mobility. Recommendation: Continue to monitor Leo's development, focusing on encouraging crawling and social interaction. Provide anticipatory guidance to the mother regarding age-appropriate activities and potential interventions if developmental delays persist. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 3 months.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: No lab results available for this visit.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Alert and active infant. Well-nourished.
Neurological: Sits unsupported briefly. Transfers objects hand-to-hand. No crawling observed.
Social: Shows anxiety with strangers. Babbles 'mama' and 'dada' without directed intent.
Musculoskeletal: Moves all extremities equally.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
Problem: Monitor developmental milestones.
Goal: Infant will demonstrate progression in motor and social skills.
Interventions:
- Encourage tummy time to promote crawling.
- Suggest age-appropriate social activities.
- Provide anticipatory guidance to parents.
- Schedule follow-up appointment in 3 months.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: No medications administered during this visit.

rows.text: Transfers objects from one hand to the other

rationale.correct: The correct answers reflect typical developmental milestones for infants. Transferring objects between hands and sitting briefly without support are expected around 6 months. Stranger anxiety and babbling without directed intent are typically seen around 12 months.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a misunderstanding of the expected age ranges for developmental milestones in infants. Review typical infant development to improve comprehension.

answerBreakdown.text: Transfers objects from one hand to the other
answerBreakdown.rationale: This skill typically develops around 6 months of age as the infant's motor skills improve.

Stranger anxiety is a common developmental milestone that typically emerges around 9-12 months of age as the infant becomes more aware of familiar faces and less trusting of unfamiliar people. This aligns with the 12-month age range.
Infants typically develop the ability to sit unsupported for short periods around 6 months of age. This indicates improved core strength and balance.
Babbling without directed intent is a language milestone usually reached around 9-12 months. Before this, babbling is exploratory. At 12 months, the sounds often become more purposeful.

clinicalPearls: Developmental milestones provide a general guideline for assessing a child's progress, but individual variations are common.
Early identification of developmental delays allows for timely intervention and support.
Parental concerns should always be taken seriously and investigated thoroughly.
Always consider the whole clinical picture, including labs, vitals, and physical exam when assessing a patient.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing the expected age ranges for various developmental milestones.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully review the typical age ranges for developmental milestones and consider the context of the infant's overall development.
